snippet.title: "If A Diogenes Prefers Poverty": Lewelling Defends the Rights of the Unemployed
snippet.description:
"If A Diogenes Prefers Poverty": Lewelling Defends the Rights of the Unemployed
The word "tramp" came into common usage in the 1870s as a ... (more)
The word "tramp" came into common usage in the 1870s as a disparaging description of homeless men thrown out of work by the economic depression and forced to take to the road in search of a job or food. Many Americans viewed tramps with a combination of fear and disgust. Fears of the "tramp menace" that had been so strong in the seventies were revived during the even more devastating depression that began in 1893. Most government officials and business leaders reacted with horror at the prospect of jobless men wandering the roads. A notable exception was the Populist governor of Kansas, Lorenzo Dow Lewelling. His executive proclamation of December 4, 1893, defended the rights of the homeless against arbitrary arrest by local police. His proclamation, published in the Topeka Daily Capital on December 5, 1893, became known as the "Tramp Circular." Lewelling's sympathy for the tramping unemployed may have come, in part, from personal experience; he himself had wandered the roads in search of work in the 1870s depression. (less)
Subject:
Humanities Material Type:
Primary Source Readings Collection:
Many Pasts (CHNM/ASHP) Provider:
American Social History Project / Center for History Media and Learning Author:
Center for History and New Media/American Social History Project
Read the Fine Print

snippet.description:
Students Find Free Online Lectures Better Than What They're Paying For
Many students across the country are using free college lecture videos as ... (more)
Many students across the country are using free college lecture videos as a new kind of study aid. Some students say they prefer the free videotaped lectures to the live lectures they are paying for at their own institutions according to the Chronicle of Higher Education. (less)

snippet.title: Speaking exercise: Choosing between a town and the country
snippet.description:
Speaking exercise: Choosing between a town and the country
You listen to some statements in which people say why they prefer ... (more)
You listen to some statements in which people say why they prefer to live in a town or in the country. By listening to these statements you will learn to recognize nuances that express certain preferences. By the end of this assignment you can express your preference for living in a town or the country and defend it. (less)
